narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot more about the nuances of nationalism then I did before. I probably left class asking more questions and feeling more unsure about nationalism then I did before, which once you learn about nationalism and all its nuances and complexities, thats exactly how you should feel since there are so many different ways to look at it in academia. Really great course and I learned a lot about how complicated nationalism could be

A better understanding of what Nationalism is, how its used in the academic and formal sense over the colloquial sense, how nation-building occurs, how regional and sub-identities come into play, and how existing power structures, both elite and state, serve to construct the national identity.
I learnt about different theories around nationalism around the world
I was very glad to be able to develop and complicate my understanding of nationalist sentiment as well as its associated academic frameworks, and how it can be used for various political ends.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: class is organized well for students learning
Weaknesses: could incorporate case studies from outside of Europe more
Professor Hierro is really sweet and treats her students well. Shes also flexible and understanding which I appreciated. Discussions were also always interesting and the papers are short sizes.

The course at times has a lot of readings, and even when Professor Hierro reduced the reading load, discussions often still never managed to cover all the readings. This, of course, happens in every course. One of the strengths of the course, however, are the guest speakers who present their own research. That gives you a much better overview of the field of Nationalism studies as it exists today, which is something very cool. Quantitative studies are also included, but while I think these are very interesting and add a lot to the course, I also think that in general students are not prepared to understand the math/statistics/economics underlying them and much of the meat of these studies gets lost in discussion.

Strengths:
-wonderful professor 
-engaging teaching style 
-interesting content 
-very in depth and helpful feedback 
Weaknesses:
-sometimes a lot of readings

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a small class so discussion worked well and we did breakout rooms for more intimate conversations

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this class challenges common depictions of nationalism and fosters great discussions.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student primarily because Professor Hierro is one of the few professors at Yale that genuinely cared about her students and incorporated student feedback! Phenomenal.

Yes, I would, though I came into the class thinking I was going to get a American/ European analysis of nationalism (analyzing Trumps rise, Brexit, etc) and you get something much broader, much more global, and also theoretical. With that being said, the course does give you a much broader view of nationalism and the literature surrounding it and still recommend

Yes, but you have to be a particular type of student, I think. Specifically, I think while this course is good and solid for most anyone who would consider it, to get the most out of it, you should either be comfortable or at the very least not-afraid of empirical and quantitative methods. Secondly, the course offers an interesting balance between traditional, abstract theory, and specific case studies and specific hypotheses which is something to take into account. Professor Hierro is an absolute gem and ties everything together quite nicely!
Absolutely if you care about the content. Its a great class with a wonderful professor

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
